channel.title: Help With Different Genres
channel.description: So many amazing Auxy producers have found their genres that they excel at. So... this feed is for people who want help with other genres that they are not necessarily good at (like me with future house, chill, and melodic dubstep). I'd be willing to help people with house, trance, and progressive house. So... help the people who need help!!!! ðŸ˜„

item.title: Help With Different Genres
item.dc:creator: OIL
item.description:
Do you mean Synthwave? Because Vaporwave is usually just taking an old track, slowing it down and pitch shifting it, and adding a lot of delay.

Synthwave has a lot of arps. Like. A lot. Use minor chord arps or any inversion of them, as a suggestion. Try compress your snares and add reverb to your entire kit. Iâ€™m not entirely sure how to explain how the bass works.

Hope that helped.

Read full topic

item.title: Help With Different Genres
item.dc:creator: OIL
item.description:
A lot of the OG soundpackâ€™s sounds are built for Dubstep-py kinds of songs, so you can start there. I suggest messing around a lot with Shape and Tone and Lowpass settings to get the desired sound.

Charge tends to be a great set for Dubstep, but really, any combo of drums that have that aggressive punch to them can work well.

I havenâ€™t tried making DnB yet, so I canâ€™t help there.

Read full topic

item.title: Help With Different Genres
item.dc:creator: OIL
item.description:
I love Jazz! I donâ€™t really have a background in melodic music theory, but I do know that you can use the Blues scales to compose a majority of Jazz tracks.

Iâ€™d recommend using the Rhodes and Wurli-based sounds available as a huge part of your chord base if youâ€™re really aiming for that Jazzy feel, and if you mess with Twigâ€™s lowpass enough, you can get a sorta slap (which is funk, I know)/contra-bass feel going.

The use of guitars and other strings available (I donâ€™t have those packs, so this is speculation) can also add something more to your tracks if you want that vibe to it. Maybe thereâ€™ll be a brass section they can add later, too, for more big-band kinda stuff!

Pianos are also a must. Use Noir, Body or Origin for that full piano sound. Layer it with something else, as a suggestion. Test out sounds, but layering it with something like Lobby can give it something special.

In terms of Jazz track structureâ€¦ Jazz is a very improvisational kind of genre, so youâ€™re encouraged to find melodies and bars which play around in scales and their harmonic relatives. Odd time signatures are doable if youâ€™re willing to put in time to move stuff around (or you can wait for the possible patch for that because goddamn do I wanna write some good tracks in 5/8 and 7/8 and all those good things).

Otherwise, the genre can be really experimental. Go nuts, man!

Read full topic

item.title: Help With Different Genres
item.dc:creator: Xiejra
item.description:
One thing i noticed about Dub phizix is that he only really uses sort of bass ie. a reese bass: for this use cube and make sure you cut out the high end so bring the lowpass filter down by like 20%. Draw your bass notes on the kick and snare hits, make them last for a beat or so. Add some kinda plucky lead to play a melody during the drop. For the first drop make sure the drop is halftime. Then the second drop make it double time and try make a nice drum pattern.

Edit: You can maybe layer the bass sounds with similar sounding basses, I like to use beam. Also on cube try doubling up on octaves, gives it a nice crunchy texture.

Read full topic
